entry.title: Important Links
entry.content:
Heya everyone! A little update by my side and welcome to 2026 (‡∏á ‚Ä¢ÃÄ_‚Ä¢ÃÅ)‡∏á

I thought going through a lot of bookmarks was tiresome ‚Äî so here we are.
Below is a curated list of useful links, sorted by category. Save for later or share with friends who might need them. This list will be updated regularly as soon as I find something more.

These lists have helped me personally, so I can vouch for their reliability.

Programming & CS

  • Learn JavaScript
  • The Odin Project ‚Äì Full Stack JS / Ruby on Rails
  • Tour of Go
  • Teach yourself CS
  • ByteByteGo - Visual Guide
  • Beej‚Äôs Guide
  • Beej‚Äôs Guide to CS/SWE

Resume making

  • Xue Tech
  • wiki.developersindia
  • Harvard tips for resume

Job apply

  • JobRails
  • Glassdoor
  • Wellfound
  • Indeed
  • Linkedin
  • Hiring cafe
  • 1point3acres
  • Peerlist
  • Opportunities Corner (mainly for Students)

Interviews

  • Neetcode
  • Python for Coding Interviews
  • Leetcode Tutorial - 70+ questions in 5+ hrs
  • Leetcode
  • Codeforces (Only for Quant/trading firms)
  • CSES

Projects based Learning Blogs

  • Robert Heaton
  • Ruslan Spivak
  • Austin Henley
  • Jesse Li
  • Jeiwan
  • Kasvith
  • practical-tutorials-Github
  • Project learn
  • Codecrafters
  • Cloud & Security Projects

Libraries & Archives

  • Anna‚Äôs Archive ‚Äì Free Books & Papers
  • Library Genesis

Courses

  • MIT OpenCourseWare
  • Fireship ‚Äì Web Dev & More
  • Neetcode ‚Äì Interview Prep
  • Standford CS229 ML course by Andrew Ng
  • From TCP to HTTP by Primeagean (in Go)

Subject-Specific Guides

  • Network Programming ‚Äì Beej‚Äôs Guide
  • Intro to Data Science ‚Äì Orb Medium
  • Life, Philosophy, and Tech ‚Äì mek.fyi
  • Learn Japanese - Hayai
  • learn Anything

Miscellaneous Resources

  • The Programmer‚Äôs Hangout ‚Äì Resource Hub
  • Pragmatic Engineer
  • Quick Reference any lang
  • Atlas - GPT for Academics

Checklist (for you, maybe?)

  • Bookmark this page
  • Share with friends
  • Actually explore the links üòÖ

‚ÄúKnowledge is power. Applied knowledge is superpower.‚Äù
‚Äî Anonymous

Let me know if you come across any other gems worth adding!

entry.title: RESUME 101 | DSCmatter
entry.content: This is where it all began.Our ancestors needed some way ‚Äî a document, really ‚Äî to verify a candidate‚Äôs abilities and determine whether they were eligible for a job.So they came up with what we now know as a CV or Resume.Now, having a good or bad resume doesn‚Äôt necessarily define a candidate‚Äôs worth ‚Äî but it does help assess whether they might be capable of doing the job.In essence, a resume is just a filtering tool ‚Äî used to weed out most candidates in what‚Äôs known as the initial screening stage.Once that filter does its job, the remaining candidates are contacted via email by HR, usually to schedule interviews and evaluate their skills more directly.After a few interviews, you might get the offer…Or you might get rejected in the final round…Or the company might cancel the entire hiring process altogether.We never know.But what can we do?Well ‚Äî we shut up, and just keep applying. Keep interviewing. Keep showing up.It‚Äôs a long, tiring process. Sometimes it takes a month or two, depending on the company.Big companies, especially, receive thousands of applications for a single role.And for senior positions?Yeah… we don‚Äôt talk about that.Let‚Äôs focus on Intern/Fresher roles:Here are some resume tips I personally vouch for.(Some people might have different opinions ‚Äî and that‚Äôs okay. The goal is to read, think, and decide what works for you.)That said…Think of this as your no-fluff crash course on crafting a resume that actually gets noticedLet‚Äôs break it down.What kind of job do you want to get? Front-end Web? Back-end Web? Enterprise applications? a job in C++ building databases? games industry?Each job roles requires different set of skills or a overalp can occur most likely in tech.So it‚Äôs important to know what someone‚Äôs hoping for and to tailor accordingly.What sort of position are you hoping to get?Intern, Junior, Senior, Director?Find what you are passionate about.Like to do Youtube? Finance? Tech? or perhaps you just love money?Try to reduce the verbosity of the resume, even if it makes it look more sparse ‚Äì people will skim this only. Words you don‚Äôt need mean the words you want them to read are less likely to be what they see.Fewer but better projects beats greater in number but lesser in variety, If you have 8 projects, don‚Äôt list them all on a resume ‚Äìmakes it too busy.Trimming out certain things that the audience(HR) knowsyour target audience knows what these things are and doesn‚Äôt need to be told:For example:Try to quantify if you can but don‚Äôt put uneccessary numbers;Use STAR methodology if possible ‚ÄìLinkBe bold. Don‚Äôt be afraid to have blank spaceOrder of sections matter:Include any kind of experience ‚Äìbetter than having not at all.Don‚Äôt explain well known terms as filler words.Keep boldiing consistent or rather not have any bolding at all.A lot of people will tell you to do that sort of thing, and to add numbers everywhere ‚Äúimproved by X%!‚Äù (as I did but keep it realistic), any human seeing your resume will immediately be exasperated by it.Sure it looks good though.As an intern or graduate, we look for coachability / willingness to learn, and we try to gauge the applicant‚Äôs enthusiasm for CS as well as just how intelligent they are (basically the gradient we expect them to be on / how fast we think they will learn).If we give you a problem in an interview, and you blitz through it but don‚Äôt listen to the interviewer trying to prod you, you did worse than someone who was less confident but that was engaging in discussion well.In an interview, take time to understand the problem clearly.If it‚Äôs unfamiliar, don‚Äôt panic ‚Äî explain what you do understand, try to reason through it, and don‚Äôt hesitate to ask the interviewer for hints.(It‚Äôs okay to not know everything ‚Äî it‚Äôs not a stupidity contest üòä)This list will be continuously updated. Feel free to suggest anything.Acknowledgments:@deadly_pineapple@boxoftruth@rsmah
entry.summary: This is where it all began. Our ancestors needed some way ‚Äî a document, really ‚Äî to verify a candidate‚Äôs abilities and determine whether they were eligible for a job. So they came up with what we now know as a CV or Resume. Now, having a good or bad resume doesn‚Äôt necessarily define a candidate‚Äôs worth ‚Äî but it does help assess whether they might be capable of doing the job. In essence, a resume is just a filtering tool ‚Äî used to weed out most candidates in what‚Äôs known as the initial screening stage.

entry.title: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33, The Best Turn Based RPG ever | DSCmatter

link.title: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33, The Best Turn Based RPG ever | DSCmatter

entry.content: A really, really great game from such a small team ‚Äî truly a contender for GOTY!My playtime was around 36 hours, and it was one hell of a journey.Although I don‚Äôt usually write much about games, this was one unforgettable experience!And since I‚Äôve started this blog, I figured I might as well write something.Turn-based RPGs hold a special place in my heart.As someone who has played Persona 3 Reload, Refantazio, and the Pok√©mon games, this one felt like a fresh take‚Äîalmost like a AAA-quality title from a smaller team.Even though I couldn‚Äôt enjoy the full glory of its graphics due to my aging GTX 1650, it still looked great on low settings.I genuinely loved every moment‚Äîthe battles, the story, and above all, the music.It‚Äôs the kind of soundtrack that stays with you‚Äîemotional, immersive, and addicting, even after the credits roll.Remember, Tomorrow comes.Below, I‚Äôve embedded the soundtrack. Feel free to give it a listen:
entry.summary: The GOAT of 2025 A really, really great game from such a small team ‚Äî truly a contender for GOTY! My playtime was around 36 hours, and it was one hell of a journey. Although I don‚Äôt usually write much about games, this was one unforgettable experience! And since I‚Äôve started this blog, I figured I might as well write something. Turn-based RPGs hold a special place in my heart. As someone who has played Persona 3 Reload, Refantazio, and the Pok√©mon games, this one felt like a fresh take‚Äîalmost like a AAA-quality title from a smaller team.
